He says when the army does go on the offensive, it usually does so from a distance, with artillery, tanks, helicopters or fighter planes, so conscripted soldiers won't come face-to-face with their own countrymen.

But, White says, there is still a hard core of soldiers loyal to the regime who are willing to kill civilians.
One thing they've done is they have tried to break the connection between the Syrian people and the rebels.
You know, that is, they inflict maximum damage, violence, against any town or area that supports the rebels.
And I believe the regime thinks that if they can break that connection, if they can get the people to reject the Free Syrian Army, then they can win the war.
Emile Hokayem is a Middle East analyst for the London-based International Institute for Strategic Studies.
